com.camerontec.util.data

Class BytesSegment

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.camerontec.util.data.BytesSegment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ExternalizableData, IDataExternalizable, Externalizable, Serializable, Cloneable

    public class BytesSegment
extends Object
implements Cloneable, Externalizable, IDataExternalizable, ExternalizableData
    Simple container for data that defines a segment of a byte array.

    The segment is defined by the array itself, a start index into the array and the number of bytes from that start index.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • BytesSegment

        public BytesSegment()
        Empty segment definition.

      • BytesSegment

        public BytesSegment(byte[] bytes,
                    int start,
                    int length)
        Creates a segment definition.

        The segment is defined as: 

           bytes[ start ] ... bytes[ start + length -1 ]
        Parameters:
        bytes - Array containing the bytes that make up the segment.
        start - Start index of the segment within the array.
        length - Number of bytes starting from start.

      • BytesSegment

        public BytesSegment(byte[] bytes)
        Convenience constructor to create a BytesSegment that stretches over the whole underlying array. This is equivalent to calling new BytesSegment(bytes, 0, bytes.length).
        Parameters:
        bytes - Array containing the bytes that make up the segment.

    • Method Detail

      • getBytes

        public byte[] getBytes()
        Returns:
        the bytes

      • setBytes

        public void setBytes(byte[] bytes)
        Calling setBytes(null) is the equivalent to calling clear()
        Parameters:
        bytes - the bytes to set

      • wrap

        public void wrap(BytesSegment segment)
        Wrap the specified segment.

        Any existing array and associated state is lost.

        This is conceptually equivalent to new BytesSegment(byte[], int, int), but without the extra object creation.

        Parameters:
        segment - BytesSegment to wrap

      • wrap

        public void wrap(byte[] bytesToWrap,
                 int startOffset,
                 int numberOfBytes)
        Wrap the specified array.

        Any existing array and associated state is lost.

        This is conceptually equivalent to BytesSegment(byte[], int, int), but without the extra object creation.

        Parameters:
        bytesToWrap - Array containing the bytes that make up the segment.
        startOffset - Start index of the segment within the array.
        numberOfBytes - Number of bytes starting from start.

      • wrap

        public void wrap(byte[] bytesToWrap)
        Wrap the specified array.

        Any existing array and associated state is lost.

        Parameters:
        bytesToWrap - Array containing the bytes that make up the segment.

      • wrap

        public void wrap(String string)
        Wrap the specified string.

        Any existing array and associated state is lost.

        Parameters:
        string - The string containing the bytes that make up the segment. It is assumed all bytes are to be part of the segment,

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Clear completely, including the reference to the contained byte array.

        On return this object no longer contains an underlying byte array.

      • clearSegment

        public void clearSegment()
        Clear the segment state but retain the contained byte array.

        This method is designed to be used when it is desirable to reuse the contained byte array.

      • clone

        public BytesSegment clone()
        Overrides:
        clone in class Object

      • copyBytes

        public byte[] copyBytes()
        Get a copy of 'valid' bytes from the segment. It copies only the relevant part of byteSegment without the 'rubbish' before 'start' and after 'start+length'. It is very similar to clone @see #clone() NOTE: This method is expensive: 1) it allocates memory 2) Uses memory copy. If you can avoid using it then it is better. In some circumstances it is better to change the code to handle directly ByteSegments.
        Returns:
        a copy of valid byte array

      • copy

        public void copy(BytesSegment source)
        Note that copy will create a copy which "equals" the source BytesSegment but in which start will always equal 0, and the bytes array may be smaller.

        However, the actual bytes in the two segments identified by their starts and length will be identical.

        Parameters:
        source - BytesSegment to copy from.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object anObject)
        Equal if other object is a BytesSegment and the bytes in the two segments are identical - irrespective of the bytes outside the segment if any.
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object

      • equalsReference

        public boolean equalsReference(Object other)
        Returns whether this segment references the some underlying byte array in the same way as another segment.

        Note that is a stricter check than equals(Object) as no byte-wise comparison is made.

        Parameters:
        other - The object with which to compare.
        Returns:
        Returns true iff other references the same underlying byte array in the same way (i.e. start and length) as this object, false otherwise.

      • grow

        public void grow(int newSize,
                 boolean doubleAtLeast)
        If necessary, increases the size of the underlying bytes array by allocating a new byte[], copying all the bytes from the existing byte array, then assigning the new byte[] as the array associated with this BytesSegment.

        Note that this may not be desired behaviour if you wish to retain a reference to a particular underlying byte[].

        Parameters:
        newSize - New capacity. Ignored if not greater than current bytes.length.
        doubleAtLeast - If true the size will always at least double, otherwise the new size will be precisely newSize.

      • size

        public int size()
        Returns the size of the underlying byte array. This is a shorthand for getBytes().length
        Returns:
        the size of the underlying byte array.

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Returns true if, and only if, size() is 0.
        Returns:
        true if size() is 0, otherwise false

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns a hash code for the bytes in the segment.

        Note that only the bytes in the segment contribute to the hash. It does not matter where the bytes appear in the underlying array - ie "start" does not matter.

        Note also that this uses the same hash formula as the standard Java String object - see String JavaDoc.

        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        a hash code value for this object.

        Returns the nth byte from the segment.
        Parameters:
        index - The index of the byte in the segment.
        Returns:
        the nth byte from the segment.

      • toHexString

        public static String toHexString(byte[] bytes,
                                 int start,
                                 int length,
                                 String separator)
        Convert a byte array into a string hex representation.
        Parameters:
        bytes - The byte array containing the bytes to convert.
        start - The offset at which to start the conversion.
        length - The number of bytes to include in the conversion.
        separator - The separator to be included between hex byte boundaries. This may be null if no separator is required.
        Returns:
        The converted hex string. The format is two hex digits per byte, separated by the given separator if it is not null.

      • toHexString

        public static String toHexString(byte b)
        Convert a byte to a 2 character, 0 filled hex String.
        Parameters:
        b - The byte to convert
        Returns:
        The resultant 0 filled hex string.

      • readExternal

                  throws IOException,
                         ClassNotFoundException
        Specified by:
        readExternal in interface Externalizable
        Throws:
        IOException
        ClassNotFoundException

      • writeExternal

        public void writeExternal(ObjectOutput out)
                   throws IOException
        Note that only the relevant bytes are written, not the whole byte array.

        This means that when it is read back, start will always be 0. However, what is read back will "equal" the written value as defined by equals(Object).

        Specified by:
        writeExternal in interface Externalizable
        Parameters:
        out - the stream to write the object to
        Throws:
        IOException - Includes any I/O exceptions that may occur
